clinical_study.brief_title: The Use of Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS) to Estimate Intracranial Pressure (ICP)
clinical_study.official_title: The Use of Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS) to Estimate Intracranial Pressure (ICP)

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to determine whether we can predict the intracranial pressure using near infra-red spectroscopy

detailed_description.textblock:
The management of intracranial hypertension requires the presence of an intracranial pressure monitor. We are investigating whether the waveforms obtained from a near infrared spectroscopy device can predict what the intracranial pressure is non-invasively.
- Patients with intracranial hypertension who are intubated and ventilated in the ICU will be recruited
- we will record there intracranial pressure and systemic arterial pressure
- recordings from the near infrared device will be recorded and analysed off-line
- we will correlate the waveform tracings from near infrared spectroscopy and the arterial tracing

primary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed while an arterial line and intracranial pressure monitor is present duing the ICU admission. This is expected to be an average of 5 days.
primary_outcome.description: Intracranial elastance (δP/δV)will be measured by dividing the pulse pressure of an invasive arterial blood pressure by the amplitude of high frequency oscillations in the near infrared (NIR) absorbance waveforms.

study_pop.textblock: Patients in the ICU with intracranial hypertension, being monitored with an arterial catheter and intraranial pressure monitor

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Patients with an intracranial pressure monitor and arterial catheter who are admitted to the ICU
Exclusion Criteria:
Less than 18 years
